title: DEXA Scans and Body Composition
content: DEXA scans are a type of x-ray that scans your body and divides tissue into bone, fat, and 'other', which is mostly muscle but also includes organs. It's very accurate at measuring fat, and total body fat divided by total body weight gives your body fat percentage. It's recommended to get DEXA scans at least once a year.

title: Understanding DEXA Scan Results
content: When reviewing DEXA scan results, four things are typically explained. First, the body fat percentage, which is the least interesting metric. Second, visceral adipose tissue (VAT), which is one of the compartments of fat that is outside of the subcutaneous stores. Third, bone mineral density, which is important for diagnosing conditions like osteopenia and osteoporosis. Fourth, metrics of muscle mass, including appendicular lean mass index (ALMI) and fat-free mass index (FFMI).

title: Importance of Tracking Health Data Over Time
content: Keeping track of health data such as DEXA scan results and blood labs over time is important for monitoring changes and trends. This can help to understand how different factors such as diet, exercise, and the passage of time are impacting health and body composition.

title: Impact of Different Diets and Exercise Regimes on Body Composition
content: Different dietary approaches (ketosis, fasting, high protein, etc.) and training protocols (primarily endurance, primarily strength training, etc.) can have varying impacts on body composition and blood biomarkers. Tracking these changes over time can help to understand the effects of these different approaches.

title: DEXA Scan Results May 2011
content: Body weight = just under 179.6 lbs. Lean mass (muscle and organs) = 155.9 lbs. Fat mass = 16.8 lbs. BMC (bone mineral content) = 7.0 lbs. FFM (Fat Free Mass), aka the sum of lean mass and BMC = 162.9 lbs. % body fat = 9.3%. VAT is unknown — unfortunately, this is back when they just didn’t have the software to show VAT.

title: Exercise and Nutrition May 2011
content: Exercise: Swimming a ton in the pool. Lifting weights like crazy. Doing a bit of cycling as kind of cross-training. Nutrition: On a carb-restricted diet but not a ketogenic diet. This was actually RIGHT BEFORE starting a ketogenic diet.

title: DEXA Scan Results August 2011
content: Lost about 7 lbs (From 180 lbs to 172.5 lbs). Lean mass went down about 3.5 lbs. Total fat went down by about 4 lbs. BMC doesn’t change. Body fat % went down to 7.5%. FFMI (Fat-free mass index) has also gone down a little bit to 23.

title: DEXA Scans 2012-2014 during Ketogenic Diet
content: Lowest weight captured on a DEXA was in October of 2012 and that was 167.5 pounds. By that point, lean mass was down to about 145 pounds. BF % was 9.5%. FFMI is still about 22.

title: Exercise and Nutrition 2012-2014
content: Exercise: Transitioned into cycling. Cycling 5 days a week. Still lifting weights, but not quite as much. Nutrition: Ketogenic diet. Not really experiencing any downside of a ketogenic diet, other than the restriction that obviously comes from it.

title: Getting off the Ketogenic Diet
content: Decided in the middle of 2014 to get off a ketogenic diet. While all metrics of health were really good (e.g., blood markers were great, performance was great, etc.). Started to experiment with fasting.

title: Blood Biomarkers for Evaluating Metabolic Health
content: Pay attention to lipids, both advanced and simple lipids. Triglycerides are always something to pay a lot of attention to. Fasting glucose, fasting insulin, insulin response, homocysteine, C-reactive protein were all in good shape. Testosterone bounced back in a big way, solidly into the 30th to 40th percentile. Uric acid was persistently elevated back in the keto days. Liver enzymes during ketosis, were at good levels (always in the twenties).

title: DEXA Scan in 2020 after Several Years of Regularly Engaging in Time-Restricted Feeding and Prolonged Fasting Protocols
content: Total Body weight only increased 0.8 pounds from 2014 to 2020. Changes to activity level: Stopped cycling competitively. Had one or two years where exercise was aimless and meandering. Never stopped exercising and training volume only went down slightly. Started doing time-restricted feeding (TRF) and prolonged fasting.

title: Fasting Protocols and Health
content: From 2017-2018, a seven day of water-only fast was done once a quarter. By 2019, this changed to three day water-only fasts once per month. The belief was that the net benefits of fasting made sense. A lot of good things happen when you’re not eating—our bodies evolved some remarkable mechanisms by which to be efficient with nutrients in their absence. We’re very good at recycling parts. We’ve had several podcasts where we talk about autophagy and what happens when nutrients are scarce. So the motivation was “this is a really healthy thing to be doing and this is a great part of my longevity toolkit”.

title: Body Composition Changes
content: The more important change would be his body composition: Fat mass basically DOUBLED from 14.3 pounds to 27.6 pounds (13.3 lb increase). His lean mass dropped from 150 to 137.5. That translated to an increase from 8.4% up to 16.1% in body fat percentage.

title: Nutritional Approach
content: His fasting was once a quarter, seven days or once a month, three day fast. He was restricting junk food. But he wasn’t deliberately restricting macronutrients of any sort. He was mostly mindful of not eating crap, but he was never really restricting intake.

title: Shifting Focus to Adding Muscle
content: Three fundamental changes for Peter between Dec 2020 and Feb 2022: 1 – He stopped fasting altogether. 2 – Protein consumption became the only macronutrient in consideration when it came to his nutrition. He adopted the goal of hitting one gram per pound of body weight. 3 – He added a day of lifting weights.

title: Changes in Blood Biomarkers
content: From 2014 to 2020, Peter was doing a lot of TRF and fasting. During 2020-2021, he dropped fasting and pivoted to focusing on protein intake. Did anything change (good or bad) in terms of his blood biomarkers? No appreciable change in biomarkers is the short answer.

title: Impact of Shoulder Surgery on Health
content: A month after his February 2020 DEXA scan, Peter has shoulder surgery on March 21st. He entered surgery at about 187 lbs, and by the end of April (one month later), Peter’s body weight dropped down to about 172 lbs — “insanely quick” drop. He was only inactive for a total of two days.

title: Impact of Stress on Health
content: Around the summer of 2022, Peter was under more stress than he’s ever felt. Writing his book, Outlive, was a big factor in the stress — “The irony of writing this book on longevity is killing my longevity”. At this time, Peter made a conscious decision: His sleep is going to stay good. He was not going to sacrifice exercise. He’s not going to sacrifice time with family. He’s not going to drink more. But the one thing he consciously relaxed on was eating — “I’m going to make zero restrictions on what I eat, like zip and zero. If it’s in front of me and I want to eat it, I’m eating it. There’s no consideration. That was it.”

title: Weight Loss Post Surgery
content: He lost 10 pounds and hit his nadir six weeks post-op. It would be interesting to look at what’s the average weight loss and then regain in body composition change, status post hip surgery, knee surgery, shoulder surgery, etc.

title: Stress Eating
content: There’s a part of him that knows that he’s not going to eat this way for the rest of his life, so he made the decision to just enjoy this period of time. He could really sense the stress eating. In those moments of late-night stress he would walk down to the pantry and get himself a bowl of mini-wheats and “inhale them”.

title: Body Composition Changes
content: Nine months post-surgery and six months post weighing 172 pounds, he now weighed 196.3 lbs. That is 10 pounds more than he weighed preoperatively. Of all that 10 pounds that he gained since February, two of them were muscle. His VAT was unchanged. Lean mass went up slightly. Fat mass went up a lot (from 27 to 34 lbs). Body fat increased from 14.4 to 17.4%.

title: Blood Work Results
content: Triglycerides were about 45. Fasting insulin was about 7 – he’d prefer to be a 5 or 6 at the most. His testosterone remains normal at 11 nanograms per deciliter for free testosterone. Liver enzymes did go up a little bit, but he had switched to a different statin (from Pravastatin to Crestor), so it’s hard for him to interpret if there’s anything else going on.

title: Nutritional and Training Approach
content: He added blood flow restriction to his training. He gained 15 pounds and all of it was muscle. Fat mass went from 27.6 down to 27. Lean mass went from 137.5 to 153. Body weight went from 172 to 187. He is going to try something nutritionally for the next four months that he’s never done before. He is going to use the app called Carbon. It’s a great database in terms of foods. It has a built-in coach. You plug in your body weight, your goal (lose 10 lbs), and the timeframe (4 months), and that you want to preserve muscle mass.

title: Nutritional Methods of Energy Restriction
content: There are 3 nutritional methods of energy restriction: caloric restriction, dietary restriction, and time restricted feeding. Each method has its own pros and cons. Caloric restriction is the most direct way to solve the problem but it requires work. Dietary restriction can be somewhat socially restricting depending on what you pick. Time restricted feeding is conceptually the easiest but you can really get into a problem pattern around protein.

title: Thoughts on Fasting and Key Takeaways
content: He might incorporate the longer term fasting back in his life but not at the same frequency he used to. Don’t lose sight of the fact that you want to index health over weight. The most interesting insight here was how much the effect of fasting, long consistent fasting had on body composition in a negative way. You have to look at this stuff in the broader context of everything you’re doing: How is your sleep? Your overall state of your nutrition? Your blood biomarkers? Your functional metrics look like your VO2 max, your Zone 2, etc.
